title: Documentation Decay Half-Life
context: Organizations invest in documentation to ensure knowledge transfer, reduce bus factor, and onboard new team members faster. The initial documentation push produces comprehensive wikis, runbooks, and architecture decision records. But documentation has a half-life. Code changes but docs don't. APIs evolve but their docs stay frozen. Within 6 months, 30-40% of technical documentation is outdated. Within a year, it's over 50%. The problem compounds: once developers encounter outdated docs a few times, they stop trusting all documentation. They go straight to the code or ask a colleague. The documentation investment becomes a liability — worse than no docs, because outdated docs actively mislead. The team that was supposed to benefit from documentation now spends time debugging issues caused by following stale instructions.
hypothesis: Documentation ensures knowledge transfer and reduces onboarding time.

Architecture diagrams show previous state, not current

effects.label: Trust in documentation collapses
effects.impact: Developers stop reading docs after 2-3 bad experiences

children.label: Developers go straight to code, bypassing docs entirely
New hires can't distinguish current from stale docs
Tribal knowledge becomes the real documentation

effects.label: Outdated docs actively cause incidents
effects.impact: Stale runbooks lead to wrong actions during outages

children.label: Following deprecated procedures makes incidents worse
Onboarding engineers make mistakes from stale guides
Doc updates not included in sprint planning

dontIf: You're planning a one-time documentation push without a maintenance plan
Your team doesn't have a process for doc review tied to code changes
ifYouMust: Tie documentation updates to code review — no PR merges without doc updates
Add expiration dates to all docs and automate staleness alerts
Keep docs close to code (README in repo, not separate wiki)
Document decisions and context, not just procedures — decisions age better

alternatives.name: Architecture Decision Records (ADRs)
alternatives.note: Document why decisions were made — these don't go stale

alternatives.name: Living documentation from tests
alternatives.note: Tests as documentation — always current because they run in CI

alternatives.name: Code-adjacent docs
alternatives.note: Docs in the same repo as code, reviewed in the same PR

sources.title: Atlassian: The Cost of Outdated Documentation
sources.note: Survey showing developers spend 30 minutes per day dealing with outdated or missing documentation

falsifiability: Organizations with comprehensive documentation maintain accuracy above 80% at 12 months without dedicated maintenance effort
Developers consistently trust and use documentation even after encountering outdated content
One-time documentation investments produce lasting onboarding improvements beyond 6 months

seo.description: Technical documentation has a half-life — 50%+ becomes outdated within 12 months. Stale docs are worse than no docs, actively misleading developers and causing incidents.
